La premiere Commission de 1'Assemblee de la Societe des Nations a ete saisie dans sa seancedu 21 septembre 1922 de la proposition suivante du Conseil: k Le Conseil a decide de presenter la proposition suivante a P Assemblee: R L'article 4 du Pacte prevoit que le Conseil est compose de representants des prin- cipales Puissances alliees et associees et de representants de quatre autres Membres de la Societe designes par 1'Assemblee. a En outre, le Conseil peut, avec Fapprobationdelamajorite de 1'Assemblee, augmenter le nombre des membres non permanents. k En vertu de ces dispositions, le Conseil a cru desirable de porter a six au lieu de quatre le nombre des Membres de la Societe a choisir par 1'Assemblee pour etre represented au Conseil. tc Le premier alinea de Particle 4 est base sur un certain principe a 1'egard du nombre des membres permanents et celui des membres non permanents du Conseil. L/augmen- tation proposee du nombre des membres non permanents apporte a ce principe une modification sensible. Toutefois, une augmentation ulterieure du nombre des membres permanents pourra etablir le principe dont Particle 4 est 1'application, sans que la modifi- cation aujourd'hui proposee puisse &tre considered comme prejudiciable a ce retablisse- ment. (( Le Conseil prie 1'Assemblee d'approuver sa decision, conformement aux dispositions du Pacte. n La resolution soumise a. 1'Assemblee est la suivante: k L'Assemblee approuve la decision du Conseil de porter a six au lieu de quatre le nombre des Membres de la Societe devant etre choisis par 1'Assembled pour etre repre- sentes au Conseil. k Cette decision entrera en vigueur aussitot qu'elle aura ete approuvee par une major- rite de 1'Assemblee. jj La discussion qui a eu lieu a la suite de la presentation de la proposition du Conseil, a mis enrelief les deux tendances differentes qui se sont manifestoes au sein de la Commission. Le point de vue qui a retenu la minorite de la Commission, s'attachait surtout a demontrer que pareille augmen-tation rendrait difficiles a 1'avenir les deliberations du Conseil. En effet, Pon se rappelle que lors de Felaboration du Pacte, il y eut des hesitations sur le nom-bre des membres qui devaient composer le Conseil de la Societe des Nations et sur la nature de leurmandat. Au premier abord, seuls les cinq principales Puissances devaient en faire partie, mais il aparu plus tard, a la Commission reunie a 1'Hotel Crillon, qu'il etait necessaire d'admettre a titrenon permanent au sein du Conseil, quatre autres Puissances. Cette composition nouvelle laissaitintacte la superiorite numerique des membres permanents. Mais du fait de 1'absence de 1'une d'elles,cette situation fut altered au detriment des grandes Puissances. Le Conseil devant etre le reflet de la situation des Puissances, il ne serait pas sage que les Etatsdont 1'importance est moindre aient en apparence, et du fait de leur nombre, une preponderancesur les grands Etats. Cette proportion nouvelle viendrait au detriment de la Societe des Nations,car la tentation serait alors tres forte pour les grands Etats, de ne pas considerer la Societe commeForgane central de la vie internationale et de ne lui Conner que des taches accessoires. LeonBour-geois et Lord Balfour, ont adresse au President du Conseil. En voici les passages les plus impor-tants, lus pendant la seance: K En outre, le Conseil peut, avec 1'approbation de la majorite de 1'Assemblee, augmen- ter le nombre des membres non permanents. II semble que le moment soit venu pour le Conseil de considerer s'il n'y aurait pas lieu de proceder a cette augmentation. a En effet, depuis ientree en vigueur du Pacte, le nombre des Etats membres de la Societe s'est accruing dans une importante proportion par F admission de neuf Etats nou- veaux, ce qui porte a 51 le nombre des pays membres de la Societe. a D'autre part, il est tres difficile d'assurer d'une maniere equitable la repartition des sieges non permanents entre les differents pays qui, en raison d'interets communs, ont tendance a constituer des groupements. a II semble, tant pour tenir compte de 1'augmentation des Membres de la Societe que pour permettre a ceux d'entre eux qui ne sont pas representes d'une facon perma- permanente au Conseil de prendre une part, active a ses travaux, qu'il y aurait lieu de porter le nombre des sieges non permanents de 4 a 6. K Nous ne devons pas ignorer que, si cette solution etait adoptee, on pourrait faire remarquer que la composition nouvelle du Conseil serait de quatre Etats permanents et six Etats non permanents, tandis que le Pacte avait prevu cinq Etats permanents et quatre Etats non permanents. Mais il ne semble pas qu'il y ait lieu de s'arreter a cette remarque, puisque, d'une part, en vertu de 1'article 5 du Pacte, les decisions du Conseil sont. sauf dispositions contraires prises a 1'unanimite des Membres representes a la reunion et qu'ainsi la question de la majorite ne se pose pas pour le Conseil, et que, d'autre part, il y a lieu de prevoir, dans 1'avenir, 1'augmentation des membres perma- nents. o Les idees exprimees par la majorite de la Commission comcidaient avec celles exprimees prece-demment par les membres du Conseil, et certains des membres de la Commission ont manifesteleur reconnaissance au Conseil pour la proposition soumise par lui et pour son opportunity. Si cette proposition est acceptee, les Puissances non representees d'une facon permanenteau Conseil pourront sans doute, du fait de 1'augmentation des membres non permanents, y exercerune tres heureuse influence. Le principe de la representation des Membres de la Societe d'une faconplus equitable se trouverait ainsi consacre. II convient en effet de donner au Conseil une representation plus large, afin que les differentsgroupements politiques et les differentes civilisations y soient representes, car la vie internationalene se compose pas seulement des grands Etats. D'autres membres de la Commission ont fait valoir que les deliberations d'un Conseil plusrepresentatif ne rencontreraient pas de difficultes plus grandes du fait de 1'augmentationdu nombredes membres; 1'exemple de 1'Union pan-americaine est la pour le justifier: tous les Etats qui lacomposent sont representes d'une facon egale dans son Conseil, sans que ses deliberations en souf-frent. L'experience de trois ans a prouve que 1'antagonisme entre les grandes et les petites Puissancesn'existait pas; elle a prouve aussi qu'il etait essentiel d'avoir au Conseil des representants des Puis-sances secondaires, notamment pour la solution des questions oh les grandes Puissances n'ont pus'entendre. La Commission s'est ralliee a la proposition du Conseil, qu'elle a acceptee a la majorite desvoix et qu'elle a 1'honneur de soumettre a 1'approbation de 1'Assemblee sous la forme suivante; K L'Assemblee approuve la decision du Conseil de porter a six au lieu de quatre le nombre des Membres de la Societe devant etre choisis par 1'Assemblee pour etre represen- tes au Conseil. a Cette decision entrera en vigueur aussitot qu'elle aura ete approuvee par une major- rite de 1'Assemblee . LEAGUE OF nations report by the First Committee to the Assembly on the increase in the number of non-permanent Members of the Council.Rapporteur : M. LAPOINTE. The following proposal of the Council was referred to the First Committee of the Assemblyof the League of Nations at its meeting on September 21st, 1922: "The Council has decided to submit the following proposal to the Assembly: "Article 4 of the Covenant provides that the Council shall consist of Representatives of the Principal Allied and Associated Powers together with Representatives of four other Members of the League selected by the Assembly. " The Council may, however, with the approval of the majority of the Assembly, increase the number of non-permanent Members. " Acting under these provisions, the Council thinks it is desirable that the number of Members of the League to be selected by the Assembly for representation on the Council should now be increased from four to six. "The first paragraph of Article 4 is based on a certain principle concerning the num- ber of the permanent and of the non-permanent Members of the Council. The proposed augmentation of the number of non-permanent Members produces a considerable modifi- cation in this principle. Nevertheless, a subsequent augmentation of the number of permanent Members would re-establish the principle of which Article 4 is the application without its being possible to consider that the change proposed to-day prejudiced such re-establishment. "The Council asks the Assembly to approve this decision, in accordance with the provisions of the Covenant." The Resolution placed before the Assembly is the following: "The Assembly approves the decision of the Council that the number of Members of the League to be selected by the Assembly for representation on the Council shall be increased from four to six. "This decision shall come into force immediately after approval by a majority of the Assembly." The discussion, which took place after the proposal of the Council had been submitted, emphasised-sised the two different points of view which have developed within the Committee. The view takenby the minority in the Committee was that such an increase would place difficulties in the way of future discussions of the Council. It may be remembered that, when the Covenant was being drawn up, difficulties arose withregard to the question of the number of Members who were to form the Council of the League ofNations and also as to their term of office. At first it was decided that the Council shouldbe composed of the five principal Powers only, but later it appeared essential to the Committeewhich met at the Hotel Crillon that four other Powers should be admitted as non-permanent members of the Council. This new formation did not affect the numerical superiority of the perma-nent Members. But should one permanent Member be absent, the proportion would be altered tothe detriment of the Great Powers. As the Council should reflect the relative position of the Powers, it would not be wise to allowStates of less importance to appear, in point of number, to preponderate over the great States.If this new proportion were introduced, the League of Nations would suffer, as there would then be astrong temptation for the great States not to regard the League as the central organ of international life but only to entrust it with minor tasks. The views of the minority would be justified in themore or less near future by any increase made in the permanent Members of the Council, whichwould thus become an overweighted and possibly ineffective body, hindering the free activity of theLeague and, in consequence, weakening the influence of the Assembly.' Moreover, it was stated that, in putting forward the proposal, the Council did not give sufficient 'reasons for its advantages. It must, however, be emphasised that the motives which prompted the Council in framingits Resolution were very clearly set forth in the letter addressed to the President of the Council by two of its Members, M. Leon Bourgeois and Lord Balfour. The most important passages of this letter, which were read during the meeting, are as follows: "The Council may, however, with the approval of the majority of the Assembly, increase the number of non-permanent Members. The moment would seem to have arrived for the Council to consider the advisability of effecting this increase. "Since the coming into force of the Covenant, the number of States Members of the League has been considerably increased by the admission of nine new States, which raises the number of States Members of the League to 51. "Furthermore, it is very difficult to ensure an equitable allocation of the non-perma- nent seats among the different countries which, owing to common interests, have a tenden- cy to form themselves into groups. "In view of the increase in the Members of the League, and in order to allow those Members which are not permanently represented on the Council to take an actve part in its work, it seems advisable to increase the number of non-permanent seats from four to six. "We must not lose sight of the fact that, if this solution were adopted, the criticism might be made that the new formation of the Council would consist of four permanent States and of six non-permanent States, whereas the Covenant lays down that it should consist of five permanent States and four non-permanent States. But this objection can hardly be considered a serious one, since, by Article 5 of the Covenant, the decisions of the Council are except where otherwise provided taken unanimously by the Members represented at the Meeting. The question of a majority therefore does not arise as far as the Council is concerned. It is advisable, moreover, to provide for a future increase of permanent Members." The ideas of the majority of the Committee coincide with those of the Members of the Council,and certain Members of the Committee have expressed their gratitude to the Council for the propo-sal which it has so opportunely put forward. If this proposal is accepted, the Powers which are not permanently represented on the council will doubtless be able to exercise a very favourable influence upon it by reason of the increase inthe number of the non-permanent Members. The principle of representation of Members of theLeague in a more equitable proportion would thus be established. It is advisable to give the Council a wider representation in order that the different politicalgroupings and the different forms of civilisation may be represented on it, since it is not the greatStates alone which count in international life. Other Members of the Committee pointed out that a more representative Council would notencounter increased difficulties in debate owing to the fact that the number of its Members had beenaugmented. The example of the Pan-American Union would justify such a measure, all the Statesof which it is composed being equally represented on its Council without any detriment to thediscussions. The experience of three years has proved that no antagonism existed between the great andthe small Powers. It has also proved that it is essential to have in the Council representatives of secondary Powers, especially for the purpose of solving questions on which the Great Powers havenot been able to come to an agreement. The Committee agreed to the proposal of the Council and adopted it by a maj ority. It has the honour to submit it for the approval of the Assembly in the following form: "The Assembly approves the decision of the Council to increase the number of Members of the League chosen by the Assembly for representation on the Council from four to six. "This decision shall come into force as soon as it shall have been approved by a major- rity of the Assembly."

RESOLUTION ADOPTED BY THE ASSEMBLY AT ITS MEETING HELD ON MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 25th, 1922 (MORNING). (Adopted on the report of the first Committee). The Assembly approves the decision of the Council to increasethe number of Members of the League chosen by the Assembly for represent-ation on the Council from four to six.
